name: Jacqueline Ferrand
content:
Jacqueline Lelong-Ferrand (17 February 1918, Alès, France – 26 April 2014, Sceaux, France) was a French mathematician who worked on conformal representation theory, potential theory, and Riemannian manifolds. She taught at universities in  Caen, Lille, and Paris.[1][2][3]
 Ferrand was born in Alès, the daughter of a classics teacher, and went to secondary school in Nîmes.[4]
In 1936 the École Normale Supérieure began admitting women, and she was one of the first to apply and be admitted. In 1939 she and Roger Apéry placed first in the mathematics agrégation; she began teaching at a girls' school in Sèvres, while continuing to do mathematics research under the supervision of Arnaud Denjoy, publishing three papers in 1941 and defending a doctoral thesis in 1942.[4][5][6] In 1943 she won the Girbal-Baral Prize of the French Academy of Sciences, and obtained a faculty position at the University of Bordeaux. She moved to the University of Caen in 1945, was given a chair at the University of Lille in 1948, and in 1956 moved to the University of Paris as a full professor. She retired in 1984.[4][5][7]
 Ferrand had nearly 100 mathematical publications, including ten books,[5] and was active in mathematical research into her late 70s.[4] 
One of her accomplishments, in 1971, was to prove the compactness of the group of conformal mappings of a non-spherical compact Riemannian manifold, resolving a conjecture of André Lichnerowicz, and on the basis of this work she became an invited speaker at the 1974 International Congress of Mathematicians in Vancouver.[4][7]
 She married mathematician Pierre Lelong in 1947, taking his surname alongside hers in her subsequent publications[5] until their separation in 1977.[4][7]
raw:
French mathematician
Jacqueline Lelong-Ferrand (17 February 1918, Alès, France – 26 April 2014, Sceaux, France) was a French mathematician who worked on conformal representation theory, potential theory, and Riemannian manifolds. She taught at universities in  Caen, Lille, and Paris.[1][2][3]

Contents

1 Education and career
2 Contributions
3 Personal life
4 References
5 Links


Education and career[edit]
Ferrand was born in Alès, the daughter of a classics teacher, and went to secondary school in Nîmes.[4]
In 1936 the École Normale Supérieure began admitting women, and she was one of the first to apply and be admitted. In 1939 she and Roger Apéry placed first in the mathematics agrégation; she began teaching at a girls' school in Sèvres, while continuing to do mathematics research under the supervision of Arnaud Denjoy, publishing three papers in 1941 and defending a doctoral thesis in 1942.[4][5][6] In 1943 she won the Girbal-Baral Prize of the French Academy of Sciences, and obtained a faculty position at the University of Bordeaux. She moved to the University of Caen in 1945, was given a chair at the University of Lille in 1948, and in 1956 moved to the University of Paris as a full professor. She retired in 1984.[4][5][7]

Contributions[edit]
Ferrand had nearly 100 mathematical publications, including ten books,[5] and was active in mathematical research into her late 70s.[4] 
One of her accomplishments, in 1971, was to prove the compactness of the group of conformal mappings of a non-spherical compact Riemannian manifold, resolving a conjecture of André Lichnerowicz, and on the basis of this work she became an invited speaker at the 1974 International Congress of Mathematicians in Vancouver.[4][7]

Personal life[edit]
She married mathematician Pierre Lelong in 1947, taking his surname alongside hers in her subsequent publications[5] until their separation in 1977.[4][7]

^ Lelong-Ferrand profile; accessed 5 May 2014. (in French)

^ a b c d e f O'Connor, John J.; Robertson, Edmund F., "Jacqueline Ferrand", MacTutor History of Mathematics archive, University of St Andrews.

^ a b c d Biographies of Women Mathematicians, Agnes Scott College; accessed 5 May 2014.

^ a b c Kosmann-Schwarzbach, Yvette (2015), "Women mathematicians in France in the mid-twentieth century", BSHM Bulletin: Journal of the British Society for the History of Mathematics, 30 (3): 227–242, arXiv:1502.07597, Bibcode:2015arXiv150207597K, doi:10.1080/17498430.2014.976804, S2CID 119148294.
